newsitem.title: GREECE: GREEK TELECOM LOOKS TO SIEMENS/INTRACOM FOR GEAR.
newsitem.headline: GREEK TELECOM LOOKS TO SIEMENS/INTRACOM FOR GEAR.

text.p: Greek state telecom OTE looks set to buy 335,000 digital switches, worth some 13 billion drachmas, from local supplier Intracom and Siemens Hellas, a subsidiary of Germany's Siemens AG.
OTE board president Dimitris Papoulias told reporters OTE was setting up a committee grouping U.S. Bellcore, Telecom Italia and Price Waterhouse to negotiate with Siemens Hellas and Intracom.
"They will have a month to negotiate a deal and then we will decided what to do and how to assign the contract," he said after a board meeting on Thursday evening.
Papoulias said OTE had "urgent need" of the switches so that they can be installed in the first half of 1997 to meet OTE's pledge to its new shareholders.
The Greek government floated eight percent of OTE last year and plans another limited float in 1997. Its shares closed at 4,050 drachmas on Thursday, just above the 4,000-drachma initial offer price.
The three-company committee will also advise OTE on plans to buy two million more digital switches for the 1997-2000 period.
OTE bought one million digital switches from Siemens Hellas and Intracom in 1994, paying 50 billion drachmas.
